original_content:
Weve often heard you should do everything twice. The first time is to learn what you need to do, and the second time is to do it right. We bet [Ian Carey] would agree after taking his old linear power supply PCB and changing it to a switching regulator design. You can see more about the project in the video below.
The first power-up revealed a problem with the 3.3V output. Weve often thought it is harder to troubleshoot a new design than it is to repair something that is known to have worked at one time.

The problem was a misread of the datasheet, something weve all done at least once. Luckily, a few component value changes cleared things up. It probably would have been feasible to repair the original boards, but it was cheap enough that he just had new boards made.
We always enjoy seeing the thought process behind a project. We also appreciate seeing the bad with the good. It is too easy to just skip to the working version and not mention the steps it took to get there, but thats where you tend to learn the most.
The video mentions how PCB layout for switchers can be a big deal, and we agree. We are always fans of switching regulator designs made to plug into linear regulator PCB footprints.
title: 旧型線形電源のPCBをスイッチングレギュレータデザインに変更
body: 電子工作において重要なのは、2度作業をすること。最初は学ぶこと、2度目は正しく行うこと。旧型の電源ボードをスイッチングレギュレーターに変更したプロジェクトが紹介されている。データシートの誤読など問題もあったが、新しいボードを作ることに成功。
